title: Campaign: Financially Motivated Actor Uses ClickFix Lures to Deploy ZAPCAT Backdoor and Provide Access to Ransomware Affiliate(s)
summary: Created: 2025-09-15 • This campaign was executed across multiple stages by two distinct threat actors: UNC6258 and UNC6259. The intrusions began with UNC6258 gaining initial access through a malicious PowerShell command that used msiexec.exe to deploy the first-stage trojan, BLACKWIDOW. Disguised as an NVIDIA executable, BLACKWIDOW utilized a DLL Search Order Hijack against libcef.dll to achieve execution and establish persistence. After securing a foothold and conducting credential theft from local browsers, the activity shifted, with the second actor, UNC6259, becoming active and deploying the second-stage implant, ZAPCAT, via rundll32.exe. ZAPCAT's primary function was to conduct extensive internal reconnaissance, focusing on Active Directory by enumerating domain trusts, Service Principal Names (SPNs), and Domain Administrator groups, alongside broader system discovery using WMI and PowerShell. This sophisticated multi-actor operation highlights the actors' proficiency in abusing legitimate system tools for malicious purposes, culminating in an attempt to pivot to other systems via SMB after obtaining necessary credentials. This handoff and methodical reconnaissance effort underscore a well-planned objective to maximize network visibility before proceeding with lateral movement.
